Table.Message: The WHD has ordered an employer in Tuscon to pay over $300,000 to employees for back pay. We are notifying our valued Arizona employers about this significant enforcement statistic to remind you of the importance of complying with federal wage & hour laws.
For Testing.

A company operating in AK will pay $77,925 to the state and cease misclassifying its employees following an investigation by the AK Department of Labor and Workforce Development. We are notifying our AK employers of this settlement to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

The EEOC has sued an Alabama employer after it allegedly discriminated against a job applicant on the basis of sex. We are notifying our valued Alabama employers about this important legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

OSHA has cited an AR employer for 1 willful, 7 serious and 1 other-than-serious violation after a worker was injured in a trench collapse. Proposed penalties total $47,600. We are notifying our AR customers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

A Tucson employer will return more than $34K in overtime and damages after improperly classifying 21 staff members as exempt from overtime. We are notifying our AZ employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

15 new laws take effect in CA starting 1/1/16. These laws address workplace issues such as equal pay, retaliation protection, E-Verify, wage payments, workplace accommodations, paid sick leave & more. Our 2016 California Employer Update Kit (CA16-KIT) addresses all these critical law changes.

A CO employer will pay $112,500 to settle an EEOC disability discrimination lawsuit after the employer terminated an employee suffering from fibromyalgia. We are notifying our CO employers about this settlement to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

OSHA has cited a Connecticut employer for 2 repeat and 3 serious safety violations. Proposed penalties total $72,000. We are notifying our Connecticut employers about this significant penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

A former employee has sued a D.C. employer for allegedly failing to pay the minimum wage under the FLSA and D.C. law. We are notifying our valued DC employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

OSHA has cited a DE employer for 1 general duty clause violation for exposing employees to heat stress, and 1 other-than-serious violation. Proposed penalties total $5,900. We are notifying our DE employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

OSHA has cited a FL employer for 10 repeat, 11 serious, and 4 other-than-serious safety and health violations. Proposed penalties total $106,000. We are notifying our valued FL employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

OSHA has cited a GA employer for 2 repeated & 6 serious safety violations after it exposed workers to fall & amputation hazards. Proposed penalties total $58,410. We are notifying our GA employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

A HI employer will pay $100K for retaliating against an employee who reported she had been sexually harassed. We are notifying our valued Hawaii employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination, harassment and retaliation laws.

OSHA has cited an Iowa employer for 1 repeated, 1 serious, and 1 other-than-serious violation for exposing a worker to excessive heat. Proposed penalties total $46,600. We are notifying our Iowa employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

OSHA has sued an ID employer for firing an employee who raised concerns about asbestos removal. OSHA is seeking reinstatement and over $300k in damages and back pay. We are notifying our valued ID employers about this lawsuit to remind you of the importance of complying with retaliation provisions.

An Illinois employer will pay $180K to settle a race and national origin harassment suit filed by the EEOC. We are notifying our valued Illinois employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO harassment and discrimination laws.

An IN employer will pay $200K to settle an EEOC sex discrimination suit to a class of women who were denied night shift employment in favor of male applicants. We are notifying our valued IN employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

The EEOC has filed suit against a KS employer for allegedly retaliating against an employee because of his grandfather's discrimination complaint against the company. We are notifying our KS employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

The DOL has ordered a KY employer to pay more than $115K to 119 workers with disabilities after failing to pay them the minimum wage. We are notifying our valued KY employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

OSHA has cited a Louisiana employer for one serious violation for failing to implement a heat management program. Proposed penalties total $7,000. We are notifying our valued Louisiana employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

The EEOC has sued a Massachusetts employer for alleged unlawful retaliation over a discrimination charge. We are notifying our MA employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination and retaliation laws.

The EEOC has filed suit against a MD employer for allegedly firing an employee because of her disability. We are notifying our MD employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

ME employers are now prohibited from requiring employees or applicants to disclose their personal social media account information, or add employers to their contact lists. Penalties could total at least $1,000. We are notifying our ME employers about this new law so you can remain in compliance.

MIOSHA has cited a MI employer for 1 serious and 4 willful serious violations after a worker died. Proposed penalties total $357K. We are notifying our MI employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with MIOSHA safety regulations.

A Minnesota employer will pay $100K to settle an EEOC disability discrimination charge for firing an Iraq war veteran because of service-related disabilities. We are notifying our valued MN employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

OSHA cited a Missouri employer for 12 serious safety violations for exposing workers to hazardous levels of a cancer-causing chemical. Proposed penalties total $74,000. We are notifying our MO employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

A MS employer will pay $100K to settle an EEOC disability discrimination for firing an employee who asked for reasonable accommodations for her disability. We are notifying our MS employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

OSHA has cited a MT employer for 21 serious and 2 other safety violations after a worker died due to acute exposure to wood dust. Proposed penalties total $50,000. We are notifying our MT employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

The EEOC has sued a NC employer for unlawful retaliation after the employer allegedly fired employees for complaining about race discrimination. We are notifying our NC employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination and retaliation laws.

OSHA has cited a ND employer for 3 willful safety violations after a worker suffered serious injuries when a platform tipped over. Proposed penalties total $105K. We are notifying our ND employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

OSHA cited a NE employer for one serious safety violation after an employee was killed while operating a crane. Proposed penalties total $7,000. We are notifying our NE employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

A NH employer will pay nearly $500K in wages and penalties after failing to pay 157 employees minimum wage and/or overtime. We are notifying our NH employers about this significant penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

OSHA has cited a NJ employer for 2 repeat and 5 serious safety violations for not providing fall protection and other safety hazards. Proposed penalties total $40,480. We are notifying our NJ employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

The DOL has ordered a NM employer to stop interfering with a wage & hour investigation and cease retaliating against workers cooperating in the investigation. We are notifying our valued NM employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

A Las Vegas employer will pay $250K to 17 workers after it missed several payrolls. We are notifying our valued Nevada employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage and hour laws.

The NY Attorney General has ordered the arrest of a NY franchisee after he allegedly failed to pay workers minimum wage & overtime. We are notifying our NY employers about this significant legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

An Ohio employer will pay nearly $383K in minimum wage and overtime pay to 29 workers after failing to proper wages. We are notifying our OH employers about this significant penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage and hour laws.

An Oklahoma employer will pay $37K in back wages after failing to pay the minimum wage and overtime to 78 employees. We are notifying our Oklahoma employers about this significant penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

An Oregon employer will pay nearly $38K in overtime wages to 32 workers after failing to compensate workers for overtime. We are notifying our valued OR employers about this significant penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

A PA employer will pay $1.4 million in back wages and damages for overtime violations to 160 employees. We are notifying our valued PA employers about this significant penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

A Puerto Rico employer will pay nearly $68K in back wages and damages for failing to pay minimum wages and misclassifying employees as independent contractors. We are notifying our PR employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage and hour laws.
test

A Rhode Island employer will pay more than $135K to 17 employees after it violated minimum wage and overtime provisions of the FLSA. We are notifying our valued RI employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage and hour laws.

The EEO has sued a SC employer for pregnancy & disability discrimination after allegedly failing to provide a pregnant employee with a reasonable accommodation. We are notifying our SC employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

The ACLU has sued a SD employer for discrimination after it allegedly forced an employee to wear a name tag with a homophobic slur on it. We are notifying our SD employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

A TN employee will pay $25K to settle an EEOC pregnancy discrimination lawsuit after the employer fired two employees because they were pregnant. We are notifying our valued Tennessee employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

A TX employer will pay $157K in back wages to 188 workers after it failed tto include the workers' bonus payments when calculating their rates of pay for overtime hours. We are notifying our valued TX employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with wage & hour laws.

OSHA has ordered a UT employer to pay $119K in wages and damages after retaliating against an employee who reported securities fraud. We are notifying our UT employers about this significant penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA whistleblowing regulations.

The EEOC has sued an Virginia employer after it allegedly failed to promote a qualified employee and then paid her less than her male coworkers. We are notifying our VA employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.

A Vermont employer will pay $22,000 to settle a lawsuit alleging employees had to perform unpaid, extra duties before and after their work shifts. We are notifying our VT employers about this settlement to remind you of the importance of complying with wage and hour laws.

The WA Department of Labor & Industries has cited a Seattle employer for 15 serious violations. Proposed penalties total $212,250. We are notifying our valued WA employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

OSHA has cited a WI employer for 2 willful and 2 other-than-serious for failing to protect workers from moving machine parts. Proposed penalties total $83,200. We are notifying our WI employers about this penalty to remind you of the importance of complying with OSHA safety regulations.

The EEOC has sued a WV employer for alleged sexual and racial harassment and retaliation. We are notifying our valued WV employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO harassment and discrimination laws.

A case against a Wyoming employer will continue after it allegedly failed to provide reasonable accommodations to a deaf employee. We are notifying our WY employers about this legal action to remind you of the importance of complying with EEO discrimination laws.
